title: 115_s1159
content: The Act may be cited as the "End Discriminatory State Taxes for Automobile Renters Act of 2017". Congress has enacted laws to prevent economic protectionism by State and local governments that discriminate against interstate commerce. In Gibbons v. Ogden, the Supreme Court affirmed Congress's sole right to regulate commerce between states under the dormant Commerce Clause. The purpose of the Act is to prohibit tax discrimination against motor vehicle rentals by State or Local governments in violation of the dormant Commerce Clause. Over 100 discriminatory taxes have been imposed since 1990. SEC. 80505 prohibits tax discrimination against motor vehicle rental property. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like assessment, assessment jurisdiction, commercial and industrial property, and commercial and industrial taxpayers. Commercial and industrial property refers to property used for commercial or industrial purposes, excluding agricultural or timber land. Commercial and industrial taxpayers are individuals or entities engaged in a trade or business. The term 'covered person' in the context of renting motor vehicles includes individuals or entities engaged in the business of renting, owning, or purchasing motor vehicle rental property. A 'discriminatory tax' is defined as a tax that discriminates against the rental of motor vehicles by imposing taxes specifically on this activity within a State or Locality. A discriminatory tax on renting motor vehicles is defined as a tax that discriminates against this business activity within a State or Locality by imposing taxes specifically on it. A discriminatory tax on renting motor vehicles is defined as a tax that discriminates against this business activity within a State or Locality by imposing taxes specifically on it, based on the tax rate exceeding the generally applicable tax rate on at least 51 percent of commercial and industrial taxpayers within the jurisdiction. The curr_chunk discusses the assessment and taxation of motor vehicle rental property, highlighting instances where it may be unfairly valued or taxed compared to commercial and industrial properties in the same jurisdiction. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to motor vehicle rental property, including 'locality,' 'motor vehicle,' 'motor vehicle rental property,' and 'rental of motor vehicles.' The curr_chunk defines terms related to motor vehicle rental property, including rentals of tangible personal property and the definition of a State for tax purposes. The term 'tax' is defined as any charge required by law to be paid to a State or Locality, excluding charges related to concession agreements at federally assisted airports or motor vehicle registration. The term 'tax base' refers to the receipts. The term 'tax base' refers to the receipts, income, value, weight, or other measure of a tax to which the rate is applied. A 'generally applicable tax' can be determined by comparing gross receipts of rentals of tangible personal property or other commercial and industrial taxpayers within a State or Locality. The text discusses discriminatory taxes on motor vehicle rentals and businesses, stating that they unreasonably burden and discriminate against interstate commerce. Such taxes are prohibited unless imposed before a certain date. The section prohibits discriminatory taxes on motor vehicle rentals and businesses, allowing covered persons to seek legal remedies in court for violations. If relief is granted, only the discriminatory portion of the tax is struck down. In subparagraph (B), a covered person must prove that a tax violates subsection (b) by a preponderance of the evidence. If the court finds a violation, the State or Locality must prove that the tax is equivalent to those imposed on other taxpayers. Other remedies under Federal or State law are not limited by this subsection. This section clarifies that it does not authorize State or Local taxation that would otherwise be prohibited. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 805 of title 49, United States Code. Rules relating to State taxation on automobile rentals are clarified in this section.
